Layer.Title: Digital Earth Australia - OGC Web Services
Layer.Abstract: Digital Earth Australia OGC Web Services

Layer.Name: ls8_nbart_geomedian_annual
Layer.Title: Surface Reflectance 25m Annual Geomedian (Landsat 8)
Layer.Abstract: Data is only visible at higher resolutions; when zoomed-out the available area will be displayed as a shaded region. The surface reflectance geometric median (geomedian) is a pixel composite mosaic of a time series of earth observations. The value of a pixel in a an annual geomedian image is the statistical median of all observations for that pixel from a calendar year. Annual mosaics are available for the following years:Landsat 8: 2013 to 2017;For more information, see http://pid.geoscience.gov.au/dataset/ga/120374For service status information, see https://status.dea.ga.gov.au

Style.Name: ndvi
Style.Title: NDVI - Red, NIR
Style.Abstract: Normalised Difference Vegetation Index - a derived index that correlates well with the existence of vegetation

Style.Name: ndwi
Style.Title: NDWI - Green, NIR
Style.Abstract: Normalised Difference Water Index - a derived index that correlates well with the existence of water (McFeeters 1996)

Style.Name: mndwi
Style.Title: MNDWI - Green, SWIR
Style.Abstract: Modified Normalised Difference Water Index - a derived index that correlates well with the existence of water (Xu 2006)

Layer.Name: ls7_nbart_geomedian_annual

Layer.Abstract: Data is only visible at higher resolutions; when zoomed-out the available area will be displayed as a shaded region. The surface reflectance geometric median (geomedian) is a pixel composite mosaic of a time series of earth observations. The value of a pixel in a an annual geomedian image is the statistical median of all observations for that pixel from a calendar year. Annual mosaics are available for the following years:Landsat 7: 2000 to 2017;For more information, see http://pid.geoscience.gov.au/dataset/ga/120374For service status information, see https://status.dea.ga.gov.au

Layer.Name: ls5_nbart_geomedian_annual
Layer.Title: Surface Reflectance 25m Annual Geomedian (Landsat 5)
Layer.Abstract: Data is only visible at higher resolutions; when zoomed-out the available area will be displayed as a shaded region. The surface reflectance geometric median (geomedian) is a pixel composite mosaic of a time series of earth observations. The value of a pixel in a an annual geomedian image is the statistical median of all observations for that pixel from a calendar year. Annual mosaics are available for the following years:Landsat 5: 1988 to 1999, 2004 to 2007, 2009 to 2011;For more information, see http://pid.geoscience.gov.au/dataset/ga/120374For service status information, see https://status.dea.ga.gov.au

Layer.Title: Landsat-8 Barest Earth
Layer.Abstract: A `weighted geometric medianâ approach has been used to estimate the median surface reflectance of the barest state (i.e., least vegetation) observed through Landsat-8 OLI observations from 2013 to September 2018 to generate a six-band Landsat-8 Barest Earth pixel composite mosaic over the Australian continent.The bands include BLUE (0.452 - 0.512), GREEN (0.533 - 0.590), RED, (0.636 - 0.673) NIR (0.851 - 0.879), SWIR1 (1.566 - 1.651) and SWIR2 (2.107 - 2.294) wavelength regions. The weighted median approach is robust to outliers (such as cloud, shadows, saturation, corrupted pixels) and also maintains the relationship between all the spectral wavelengths in the spectra observed through time. The product reduces the influence of vegetation and allows for more direct mapping of soil and rock mineralogy.Reference: Dale Roberts, John Wilford, and Omar Ghattas (2018). Revealing the Australian Continent at its Barest, submitted.Mosaics are available for the following years: Landsat 8: 2013 to 2017;

Layer.Name: ls8_barest_earth_mosaic
Layer.Title: Landsat-8 Barest Earth 25m albers (Landsat-8)
Layer.Abstract: A `weighted geometric medianâ approach has been used to estimate the median surface reflectance of the barest state (i.e., least vegetation) observed through Landsat-8 OLI observations from 2013 to September 2018 to generate a six-band Landsat-8 Barest Earth pixel composite mosaic over the Australian continent.The bands include BLUE (0.452 - 0.512), GREEN (0.533 - 0.590), RED, (0.636 - 0.673) NIR (0.851 - 0.879), SWIR1 (1.566 - 1.651) and SWIR2 (2.107 - 2.294) wavelength regions. The weighted median approach is robust to outliers (such as cloud, shadows, saturation, corrupted pixels) and also maintains the relationship between all the spectral wavelengths in the spectra observed through time. The product reduces the influence of vegetation and allows for more direct mapping of soil and rock mineralogy.Reference: Dale Roberts, John Wilford, and Omar Ghattas (2018). Revealing the Australian Continent at its Barest, submitted.Mosaics are available for the following years: Landsat 8: 2013 to 2017;For service status information, see https://status.dea.ga.gov.au

Layer.Title: Landsat 30+ Barest Earth
Layer.Abstract: An estimate of the spectra of the barest state (i.e., least vegetation) observed from imagery of the Australian continent collected by the Landsat 5, 7, and 8 satellites over a period of more than 30 years (1983 - 2018). The bands include BLUE (0.452 - 0.512), GREEN (0.533 - 0.590), RED, (0.636 - 0.673) NIR (0.851 - 0.879), SWIR1 (1.566 - 1.651) and SWIR2 (2.107 - 2.294) wavelength regions. The approach is robust to outliers (such as cloud, shadows, saturation, corrupted pixels) and also maintains the relationship between all the spectral wavelengths in the spectra observed through time. The product reduces the influence of vegetation and allows for more direct mapping of soil and rock mineralogy. This product complements the Landsat-8 Barest Earth which is based on the same algorithm but just uses Landsat8 satellite imagery from 2013-2108. Landsat-8's OLI sensor provides improved signal-to-noise radiometric (SNR) performance quantised over a 12-bit dynamic range compared to the 8-bit dynamic range of Landsat-5 and Landsat-7 data. However the Landsat 30+ Barest Earth has a greater capacity to find the barest ground due to the greater temporal depth. Reference: Roberts, D., Wilford, J., Ghattas, O. (2019). Exposed Soil and Mineral Map of the Australian Continent Revealing the Land at its Barest. Nature Communications. Mosaics are available for the following years: Landsat 5 / Landsat 7 / Landsat 8 - 1983 to 2018;

Layer.Title: Landsat 30+ Barest Earth 25m albers (Combined Landsat)
